tasks.task: Operating and maintaining a linear irrigation system
subtasks: Mentally preparing to swap hoses every 500 feet
Driving a tractor or truck to drag a hose to the next hydrant
Ensuring hydrants are not easily dislodged (located ~4 feet underground)
Monitoring hose lifespan (typically 8-10 years)
Ensuring consistent water usage compared to center pivot systems
Adjusting to labor-intensive tasks during hot weather (e.g., irrigation)
Maintaining a furrow for the linear irrigation system
Operating GPS auto steel tractors for precise furrow digging
Monitoring the linear irrigation machine's sensors to prevent water cutoff
Understanding the system's vulnerability to wheel alignment (e.g., boards or 2x4 guides)
Setting up the system to cover a square or rectangular field
Aligning the system's movement pattern (down and back) with field layout
Ensuring full coverage in straight fields without circular system edges
Adjusting to the need for manual hose swapping compared to automated center pivots
Managing system efficiency and comparing to other irrigation methods (drip vs. center pivot)

tasks.task: Addressing challenges and considerations specific to linear irrigation
subtasks: Noting the necessity for manual labor (hose swapping, furrow maintenance)
Evaluating the system's adaptability to various crops (corn, soybeans, cotton, strawberries)
Understanding the system's impact on crop management (ground-level irrigation, evaporation control)
Considering the system's longevity and replacement intervals (hydrants every 8-10 years)
Assessing the use of GPS technology in maintaining system alignment
Preparing for the potential complexity of resetting the system after hose swaps
